--- title: "Building a plot
step-by-step with ggplot2" format: revealjs --- # ggplot2 {.section-break} ## ggplot2 $\in$ tidyverse ::: columns ::: {.column width="40%"} ::: incremental - **ggplot2** is tidyverse's data visualization package ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(tidyverse) ``` ::: - *gg* in ggplot2 stands for Grammar of Graphics, inspired by the book **Grammar of Graphics** by Leland Wilkinson ::: ::: ::: {.column width="30%"} ![](images/ggplot2-part-of-tidyverse.png){fig-align="left" width="200"} ::: ::: ::: incremental - Package website: [ggplot2.tidyverse.org](https://ggplot2.tidyverse.org) - Structure of the code for plots can be summarized as ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot( data = [dataset], mapping = aes(x = [x-variable], y = [y-variable]) ) + geom_xxx() + other options ``` ::: ::: ## Mass vs. height ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="|1|2|3-7"} ggplot(starwars, aes(x = height, y = mass)) + geom_point() + labs( title = "Mass vs. height of Starwars characters", x = "Height (cm)", y = "Weight (kg)" ) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Warning: Removed 28 rows containing missing values (`geom_point()`). ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](2-1-2-step-by-step-ggplot2_files/figure-revealjs/mass-height-1.png){width=576} ::: ::: # ggplot2 ‚ù§Ô∏è üêß {.section-break} ## Data: Palmer Penguins Measurements for penguin species, island in Palmer Archipelago, size (flipper length, body mass, bill dimensions), and sex. ![](images/penguins.png){fig-align="center" width="477"} ## Data ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="|1|2"} library(palmerpenguins) glimpse(penguins) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Rows: 344 Columns: 8 $ species Adelie, Adelie, Adelie, Adelie, ‚Ä¶ $ island Torgersen, Torgersen, Torgersen,‚Ä¶ $ bill_length_mm 39.1, 39.5, 40.3, NA, 36.7, 39.3‚Ä¶ $ bill_depth_mm 18.7, 17.4, 18.0, NA, 19.3, 20.6‚Ä¶ $ flipper_length_mm 181, 186, 195, NA, 193, 190, 181‚Ä¶ $ body_mass_g 3750, 3800, 3250, NA, 3450, 3650‚Ä¶ $ sex male, female, female, NA, female‚Ä¶ $ year 2007, 2007, 2007, 2007, 2007, 20‚Ä¶ ``` ::: ::: ## Plot ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](2-1-2-step-by-step-ggplot2_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-6-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: ## Code ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot( data = penguins, mapping = aes( x = bill_depth_mm, y = bill_length_mm, color = species ) ) + geom_point() + labs( title = "Bill depth and length", subtitle = "Dimensions for Adelie, Chinstrap, and Gentoo Penguins", x = "Bill depth (mm)", y = "Bill length (mm)", color = "Species", caption = "Source: Palmer Station LTER / palmerpenguins package" ) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Warning: Removed 2 rows containing missing values (`geom_point()`). ``` ::: ::: # Coding out loud {.section-break} ## Step 1 **Start with the `penguins` data frame** ::: {.cell output-location='column'} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="|1,3|2"} ggplot( data = penguins ) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](2-1-2-step-by-step-ggplot2_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-8-1.png){width=576} ::: ::: ## Step 2 Start with the `penguins` data frame, **map bill depth to the x-axis** ::: {.cell output-location='column'} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="3"} ggplot( data = penguins, mapping = aes(x = bill_depth_mm) ) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](2-1-2-step-by-step-ggplot2_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-9-1.png){width=576} ::: ::: ## Step 3 Start with the `penguins` data frame, map bill depth to the x-axis **and map bill length to the y-axis.** ::: {.cell output-location='column'} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="4-5"} ggplot( data = penguins, mapping = aes( x = bill_depth_mm, y = bill_length_mm ) ) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](2-1-2-step-by-step-ggplot2_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-10-1.png){width=576} ::: ::: ## Step 4 Start with the `penguins` data frame, map bill depth to the x-axis and map bill length to the y-axis. **Represent each observation with a point** ::: {.cell output-location='column'} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="8"} ggplot( data = penguins, mapping = aes( x = bill_depth_mm, y = bill_length_mm ) ) + geom_point() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](2-1-2-step-by-step-ggplot2_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-11-1.png){width=576} ::: ::: ## Step 5 Start with the `penguins` data frame, map bill depth to the x-axis and map bill length to the y-axis. Represent each observation with a point **and map species to the color of each point.** ::: {.cell output-location='column'} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="6"} ggplot( data = penguins, mapping = aes( x = bill_depth_mm, y = bill_length_mm, color = species ) ) + geom_point() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](2-1-2-step-by-step-ggplot2_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-12-1.png){width=576} ::: ::: ## Step 6 Start with the `penguins` data frame, map bill depth to the x-axis and map bill length to the y-axis. Represent each observation with a point and map species to the color of each point. **Title the plot "Bill depth and length"** ::: {.cell output-location='column'} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="|6,8|7"} ggplot( data = penguins, mapping = aes(x = bill_depth_mm, y = bill_length_mm, color = species) ) + geom_point() + labs( title = "Bill depth and length" ) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](2-1-2-step-by-step-ggplot2_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-13-1.png){width=576} ::: ::: ## Step 7 Start with the `penguins` data frame, map bill depth to the x-axis and map bill length to the y-axis. Represent each observation with a point and map species to the color of each point. Title the plot "Bill depth and length", **add the subtitle "Dimensions for Adelie, Chinstrap, and Gentoo Penguins"** ::: {.cell output-location='column'} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="8"} ggplot( data = penguins, mapping = aes(x = bill_depth_mm, y = bill_length_mm, color = species) ) + geom_point() + labs( title = "Bill depth and length", subtitle = "Dimensions for Adelie, Chinstrap, and Gentoo Penguins" ) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](2-1-2-step-by-step-ggplot2_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-14-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## Step 8 Start with the `penguins` data frame, map bill depth to the x-axis and map bill length to the y-axis. Represent each observation with a point and map species to the color of each point. Title the plot "Bill depth and length", add the subtitle "Dimensions for Adelie, Chinstrap, and Gentoo Penguins", **label the x and y axes as "Bill depth (mm)" and "Bill length (mm)", respectively** ::: {.cell output-location='column'} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="9-10"} ggplot( data = penguins, mapping = aes(x = bill_depth_mm, y = bill_length_mm, color = species) ) + geom_point() + labs( title = "Bill depth and length", subtitle = "Dimensions for Adelie, Chinstrap, and Gentoo Penguins", x = "Bill depth (mm)", y = "Bill length (mm)" ) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](2-1-2-step-by-step-ggplot2_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-15-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## Step 9 Start with the `penguins` data frame, map bill depth to the x-axis and map bill length to the y-axis. Represent each observation with a point and map species to the color of each point. Title the plot "Bill depth and length", add the subtitle "Dimensions for Adelie, Chinstrap, and Gentoo Penguins", label the x and y axes as "Bill depth (mm)" and "Bill length (mm)", respectively, **label the legend "Species"** ::: {.cell output-location='column'} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="10"} ggplot( data = penguins, mapping = aes(x = bill_depth_mm, y = bill_length_mm, color = species) ) + geom_point() + labs( title = "Bill depth and length", subtitle = "Dimensions for Adelie, Chinstrap, and Gentoo Penguins", x = "Bill depth (mm)", y = "Bill length (mm)", color = "Species" ) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](2-1-2-step-by-step-ggplot2_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-16-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## Step 10 {.smaller} Start with the `penguins` data frame, map bill depth to the x-axis and map bill length to the y-axis. Represent each observation with a point and map species to the color of each point. Title the plot "Bill depth and length", add the subtitle "Dimensions for Adelie, Chinstrap, and Gentoo Penguins", label the x and y axes as "Bill depth (mm)" and "Bill length (mm)", respectively, label the legend "Species", **and add a caption for the data source.** ::: {.cell output-location='column'} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="11"} ggplot( data = penguins, mapping = aes(x = bill_depth_mm, y = bill_length_mm, color = species) ) + geom_point() + labs( title = "Bill depth and length", subtitle = "Dimensions for Adelie, Chinstrap, and Gentoo Penguins", x = "Bill depth (mm)", y = "Bill length (mm)", color = "Species", caption = "Source: Palmer Station LTER / palmerpenguins package" ) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](2-1-2-step-by-step-ggplot2_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-17-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## Step 11 {.smaller} Start with the `penguins` data frame, map bill depth to the x-axis and map bill length to the y-axis. Represent each observation with a point and map species to the color of each point. Title the plot "Bill depth and length", add the subtitle "Dimensions for Adelie, Chinstrap, and Gentoo Penguins", label the x and y axes as "Bill depth (mm)" and "Bill length (mm)", respectively, label the legend "Species", and add a caption for the data source. **Finally, use a discrete color scale that is designed to be perceived by viewers with common forms of color blindness.** ::: {.cell output-location='column'} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="13"} ggplot( data = penguins, mapping = aes(x = bill_depth_mm, y = bill_length_mm, color = species) ) + geom_point() + labs( title = "Bill depth and length", subtitle = "Dimensions for Adelie, Chinstrap, and Gentoo Penguins", x = "Bill depth (mm)", y = "Bill length (mm)", color = "Species", caption = "Source: Palmer Station LTER / palmerpenguins package" ) + scale_color_viridis_d() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](2-1-2-step-by-step-ggplot2_files/figure-revealjs/step-11-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## Plot ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Warning: Removed 2 rows containing missing values (`geom_point()`). ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](2-1-2-step-by-step-ggplot2_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-19-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: ## Code ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot( data = penguins, mapping = aes(x = bill_depth_mm, y = bill_length_mm, color = species) ) + geom_point() + labs( title = "Bill depth and length", subtitle = "Dimensions for Adelie, Chinstrap, and Gentoo Penguins", x = "Bill depth (mm)", y = "Bill length (mm)", color = "Species", caption = "Source: Palmer Station LTER / palmerpenguins package" ) + scale_color_viridis_d() ``` ::: ## Narrative Start with the `penguins` data frame, map bill depth to the x-axis and map bill length to the y-axis. Represent each observation with a point and map species to the color of each point. Title the plot "Bill depth and length", add the subtitle "Dimensions for Adelie, Chinstrap, and Gentoo Penguins", label the x and y axes as "Bill depth (mm)" and "Bill length (mm)", respectively, label the legend "Species", and add a caption for the data source. Finally, use a discrete color scale that is designed to be perceived by viewers with common forms of color blindness. ## Argument names You can omit the names of first two arguments when building plots with `ggplot()`. ::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="|2-7"} ggplot( data = penguins, mapping = aes( x = bill_depth_mm, y = bill_length_mm ) ) + geom_point() ``` ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="|2-7"} ggplot( penguins, aes( x = bill_depth_mm, y = bill_length_mm ) ) + geom_point() ``` ::: ::: :::

<script>
  // htmlwidgets need to know to resize themselves when slides are shown/hidden.
  // Fire the "slideenter" event (handled by htmlwidgets.js) when the current
  // slide changes (different for each slide format).
  (function () {
    // dispatch for htmlwidgets
    function fireSlideEnter() {
      const event = window.document.createEvent("Event");
      event.initEvent("slideenter", true, true);
      window.document.dispatchEvent(event);
    }

    function fireSlideChanged(previousSlide, currentSlide) {
      fireSlideEnter();

      // dispatch for shiny
      if (window.jQuery) {
        if (previousSlide) {
          window.jQuery(previousSlide).trigger("hidden");
        }
        if (currentSlide) {
          window.jQuery(currentSlide).trigger("shown");
        }
      }
    }

    // hookup for slidy
    if (window.w3c_slidy) {
      window.w3c_slidy.add_observer(function (slide_num) {
        // slide_num starts at position 1
        fireSlideChanged(null, w3c_slidy.slides[slide_num - 1]);
      });
    }

  })();
</script>
